questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe watery diarrhea following a recent trip to Thailand. Stool analysis reveals the presence of an E. coli enterotoxin. Which of the following tests is most indicative of a positive result for heat-stable toxin?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: Which strain of E. coli is known for its ability to adhere to intestinal epithelial cells in a distinctive "stacked-brick" arrangement, and is frequently linked to persistent diarrhea in children and individuals with HIV?
questions.explanation:
Type of E. coli

Clinical Features

Toxins Produced

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

Watery diarrhea, Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever, Nausea and vomiting

Most common cause of traveller's diarrhea

Causes watery diarrhea through

attachment via CFA (colonization factor antigen) and toxin production (heat-labile toxin ↑cAMP, heat-stable toxin ↑cGMP).

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)

Watery diarrhea (especially in infants), Fever, Vomiting, Dehydration

None (mechanism involves attaching and effacing lesions)

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

Bloody diarrhea, Severe abdominal cramps, Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Shiga-like toxins/Verocytotoxin

Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)

Watery diarrhea followed by dysentery-like symptoms, Fever, Severe abdominal pain

None (mechanism involves cell invasion and intracellular multiplication)

Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC)

Persistent watery diarrhea (duration > 14 days), Abdominal pain, Nausea, Low-grade fever

Plasmid-encoded toxin (PET)

I"stacked-brick" pattern of bacterial aggregation when adhering to HEp-2 cells.

Diffuse-adhering E. coli (DAEC)

Watery diarrhea (usually mild), Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever

None (mechanism involves diffuse adherence to epithelial cells)

options.text: Indole Test, Methyl Red (MR) Test, Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test, and Citrate Utilization Test

options.text: Gram Staining, Urease Test, Catalase Test, and Oxidase Test

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Indole Test, Methyl Red (MR) Test, Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test, and Citrate Utilization Test
questions.explanation:
Test

Result

Indole Production

E. coli is typically indole positive.

Methyl Red (MR) Test

E. coli shows a positive result.

Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test

E. coli is typically negative.

Citrate Utilization

E. coli usually does not utilize citrate (negative result).

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar

Shows fermentation of glucose, lactose, and production of gas.

Urease Test

E. coli is urease negative.

questions.text: Which toxin produced by Shigella inhibits protein synthesis in host cells and has the potential to cause hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)?
questions.explanation:
Type of Toxin

Produced By

Mechanism

Effects

Shiga Toxin (Stx)

Shigella dysenteriae type 1

Inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by cleaving a specific adenine residue from the 28S rRNA of the 60S ribosomal subunit.

Causes cell death, contributes to intestinal damage, and can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in severe cases.

Enterotoxins (ShET-1 & ShET-2) (Option A ruled out)

Various Shigella species

Induce fluid secretion in the intestine, contributing to diarrhea.

Promote diarrhea by causing fluid accumulation in the intestinal lumen.

Ipa Proteins (Option C ruled out)

-

Facilitate entry into host epithelial cells and escape from phagosomes.

Enhance bacterial invasion and survival within host cells.

IcsA (VirG) (Option D ruled out)

-

Promotes actin polymerization for intracellular movement and spread to adjacent cells.

Aids in the spread of Shigella within the intestinal epithelium.

Injected by Type III Secretion System (T3SS)

-

Proteins like IpaB, IpaC, and IpaD disrupt host cell processes, aiding in bacterial invasion and evasion of the host immune response.

Enhance bacterial survival and replication by evading host immune defenses.

Endotoxins

-

Due to the lipopolysaccharides (LPS) of the Gram-negative cell wall.

Contributes to inflammatory response and symptoms associated with infection.
